channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Want to be as welcome as a Martian in Roswell? Perl developers in Houston Texas
item.description: The client may not build rockets, but theyâ€™re a well-known company that builds the software which hosting companies use to allow their customers to host, build, and maintain websites. The software you help to create will be deployed on thousands of servers all over the internet, and scads of people will use itâ€”changes you make will be seen and used by hundreds of thousands of people, and maybe an

item.title: Enjoy Modern Perl with a properly Agile team in Manchester; mid-Level Perl Developer
item.description: The company is profitable, well-established, and family-owned, and have a strong set of benefits, not least of which a most-excellent coffee machine. The tech team itself has a real focus on collaboration while coding (pair-programming and so on), but the company also has regular non-work events too to help you feel like part of a team.

item.title: A Fang-tastic Opportunity - Perl Developer in Manchester
item.description: Picture this: Dracula is on the hunt for a flatmate. He takes a gamble on some shady guy from Craigslist, name of Van Helsing . . . and next thing you know, poor olâ€™ Drac is staked while he sleeps. But wait! Thereâ€™s a better way, and thatâ€™s where you come in.

item.title: A little bird told me this might be the job for you! Perl Developer in Canary Wharf
item.description: No stuffed shirts in this nest: this company has a start-up atmosphere without the uncertainty and uncomfortable bean bag chairs. Seriously, can anyone over twelve sit comfortably on those things? Your new teammates pride themselves on their extraordinary corporate culture, so youâ€™ll regularly find them holding Hacker Days for employees to prototype new features they think would send the company

item.title: The Step-by-Step Guide to Making your Friends Green with Envy
item.description: How many times have you been at a party and had to grin and bear it while your mates brag about their cool jobs? Robertâ€™s working from Antigua for the week, and Susanâ€™s taking yet another vacationâ€”how many days off can one woman have? Never fearâ€”weâ€™ve got the Step-by-Step Guide to Making your Friends Green with Envy.

item.title: Change offers amazing opportunites
item.description: The Camelia mascot of the language now known as Raku is a brightly coloured metaphor for the transition from Perl 6 to it's new identity.

item.title: Write YAML file
item.description: Just a simple example to copy-paste.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 30
item.description: Roger solution to the Task #2 of number series is really cool.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 30: Sunday Christmas and Triplets
item.description: Please checkout the Raku magic to solve the Christmas date task. You will be amazed.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 30
item.description: Jaldhar shared really nice tricks with regard to the Christmas day task. "Christmas always falls on December the 25th which is exacly one week before New Years Day of the next year. So if we know the next New Years Day is on a Sunday, we know Christmas is on a Sunday. How do we know which day of the week New Years Day is on? Well, January 1, 2019 was on a Tuesday. January 1, 2020 will be on the next consecutive day of the week i.e. Wednesday. For each subsequent year we increment the day of week by one. The only stumbling block is for leap years which have an extra day. So for the year after a leap year, we have to increment by two."

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 030: Sunday Christmas and Series with sum 12
item.description: Checkout the trick used by Choroba in the blog.

item.title: Blogging Challenge 30
item.description: Dave used just 2 for-loops instead of 3 to solve the number series task with a nice little hack.

item.title: Christmas Twelfth Cometh Perl 6
item.description: If you want to fall in love with Raku, just read the solution to Christmas day task by Arne. I bet you will not be disappointed.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 030
item.description: Reading Adam's blog always enjoyable, specially the section NOTE in the end.

item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.title: Why forward compatibility is important when trying to add a new grammar to Perl
item.description: Yuki started discussion about adding a new grammar to Perl.

item.title: Cor - A proposal for core Perl OO
item.description: Curtis shared the little secret project that he is working with Sawyer X and Steven Little. Please do checkout the article for more details.

item.title: Perlyglot
item.description: Our small team really enjoys organizing the mostly-annual DC-Baltimore Perl Workshop, and we're working on it again for 2020

item.title: #430 - Did you attend London Perl Workshop 2019?
item.description:
Hi there

We have had great workshop last Saturday. Lots of interesting talks to attend. It was pleasure to be part of the show. It also presented the opportunity to meet friends. As you all know, LPW moved to new venue this time, everybody liked the venue.

If you did attend the event then please do share your experience with us.

Enjoy the rest of the week.
